Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Research Culturally Based Citizen Science: Rebuilding Relationships to Place

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this three-year collaborative design research project is to examine the role of culture in the development of knowledge and reasoning about the natural world and the subsequent sense-making of and participation in natural resource management. The PIs propose to examine the ways in which culture impacts observational habits, explanation constructing, uses and forms of evidence, and orientations towards socio-scientific challenges such as natural resource management. Collaborating on this project are researchers from the American Indian Center of Chicago, Northwestern University, and the Menominee Indian Tribe of Wisconsin. The audience for this study includes the academic informal science education community and indigenous science educators. This project also offers extensive cross-cultural, cross-disciplinary research opportunities for pre- and post-doctoral research trainees.

The project will employ a mixed methods approach and proposes evaluation through an advisory board and community input. A community assessment team is proposed to review activities, obtain feedback from the larger community, and identify challenges to the effective implementation of the program. The project is comprised of two main panels of studies: the first consisting of a series of investigations of learning in everyday activities and the second consisting of two community design experiments that engage two Native American communities and two non-Native communities, one rural and one urban for both communities, in a culturally based citizen science (CBCS) project focused on ecosystem disruption (e.g. invasive species; climate change) and natural resource management. The CBCS project will engage participants in question formation, data collection, data analysis, forming policy recommendations, and citizen action around the findings. This project will develop a citizen science model that effectively engages diverse communities towards productive science learning, helpful scientific data collection, and citizen engagement in community planning and local policy decisions.

The researchers believe that fundamental advances in STEM teaching and learning are needed across the broad landscape of learning environments and that the success of such advances may pivot on innovations and discoveries made in informal environments. Insights obtained from prior research on learning in indigenous cultures, especially in biological and environmental sciences, combined with the anticipated results from this study could lead to a deeper understanding of cross-cultural similarities and differences in science learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of our project has been to examine how culture affects ways of looking at the natural world and how these ways, in turn, affect the development of knowledge and reasoning about nature.  More specifically this project explores the ways in which culture affects observational habits, explanation construction, uses of and choices of forms of evidence, and orientations towards environmental challenges like natural resource management.  The project was comprised of two main subgoals, the first consisting of a series of investigations of science learning in everyday activities and the second of community design experiments that engage two Native American communities in a culturally based citizen science (CBCS) project focused on urban foraging, ecosystem disruption (e.g. invasive species) and natural resource management. The project is a collaboration involving the University of Washington and the American Indian Center of Chicago, the Menominee Tribe of Wisconsin, and Northwestern University (see Bang et al., 2010 for an expanded discussion of this partnership).

An important facet of thinking about the biological world is the place of humans within it. We have found that some cultural groups (e.g., European Americans) tend to think of nature as separate from humans and as something that needs to be protected. Other cultural groups (e.g., Native Americans) see themselves as a part of nature. These differences are observed in surveys and a range of cognitive tasks. They are even reflected in artifacts such as children’s books authored by Native Americans versus those by non-Native authors, as well as science-related images that can be observed in science textbooks and in Google images. These various sources of evidence have provided converging evidence for cultural differences in framework theories that can be linked to science-related practices and science learning.  

The idea that humans are a part of nature has important consequences for community programming in general and Citizen Science efforts in particular, not to mention larger issues of in science education and policy making. Given limited space, we focus on some key efforts in the Chicago Indian community. The AIC is surrounded by a medicinal garden that also supports seeing Chicago as part of an urban ecosystem. Our summer youth programming has continued this urban ecology theme where our recent focus has been restoration and planting at a nearby Metra Rail embankment. Pre-test, post-test comparisons show that program participation was associated with greater knowledge of plants and plant uses, greater identification with science, and increased seeing the AIC neighborhood as part of an (urban) ecosystem.  

Rather than inviting adults to “help scientists” with some predetermined project, for Citizen Science programming we invited community members to identify goals and needs.  Community meetings led to two related themes: the need for sustainable food within the AIC community, including harvesting of traditional wild food plants that grow in Chicago; 2. exploring the use of tribal subsistence rights on ceded territory (Chicago)  for agricultural and ecosystem restoration  This led to a variety of efforts related to what one might call urban foraging (e.g. harvesting mulberries; tapping maple trees).
